afforestation and reforestation, soil carbon sequestration, and enhanced weathering.)
. Careful design of policies to shift development pathways
towards sustainability can increase synergies and manage
This section examines how development pathways can build greater adaptive and mitigative capacity,
and then turns to several examples of mitigation actions with implications
a notable link to development pathways and policy choices. These examples are in the areas of
agriculture, blue carbon and terrestrial ecosystem restoration.
Development pathways can build greater capacity for both
assessments have reflected on making development more sustainable
2014; Sathaye et al. 2007; IPCC et al. 2001)
ther assessments have highlighted how ecosystem
and are critical to meeting the goals of the Paris

support and often enable transformations and that “sustainable development has the potential to
significantly reduce systemic vulnerability, enhance adaptive capacity, and promote livelihood se

c policies and shifts in development pathways to achieve both
Governance and institutional capacity necessary for mitigation actions also enables effective adaptation
tation of mitigation and adaptation actions can, however, encounter different sets of
Mitigation actions requiring a shift away from established sectors and resources (e.g.
fuels) entail governance challenges to overcome vested interests
state actors tend to attain greater completion than adaptation
On the level of individual entities, adaptation is reactive to current or anticipated environmenta
but mitigation is undertaken deliberately. Chapter 5 considers behavioural change, including the
reconsideration of values and what is meant by well
being, and reflecting on a range of actors addressing
), and there may be limits to propensity to change.
Some studies report that climate change deniers
and sceptics can be induced to undertake pro
environmental action if those actions are framed in t
of societal welfare, not climate change
change behaviour and lifestyles include the Transition Town movement, which seeks t
Finance and investment of mitigation actions must be examined in conjunction with funding of
adaptation actions, due to biophysical linkages and policy
supports mitigation efforts, not adaptation efforts
. Mitigation projects are often more attractive to private capital
